questions.text: A patient presented with the X-ray. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Miliary TB

 

Miliary tuberculosis (TB) is characterized by the presence of numerous small nodules that are uniformly distributed throughout the lungs. These nodules are millet-seed-sized, giving a "miliary" appearance on the chest X-ray. The image provided shows these numerous tiny nodules distributed evenly across both lung fields, which is classic for miliary TB.

 

Miliary TB occurs when a large number of Mycobacterium tuberculosis organisms disseminate through the bloodstream and lodge in multiple organs, most commonly the lungs. The small size and uniformity of the nodules in the X-ray are key diagnostic features.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bronchogenic carcinoma: This typically presents as a mass lesion on an X-ray, which may cause collapse of the surrounding lung tissue. The absence of a clear mass lesion on the X-ray rules out bronchogenic carcinoma as the most likely diagnosis.

 

Option B. Aspergilloma: Aspergilloma is characterized by the presence of a fungal ball within a pre-existing lung cavity. On an X-ray, this would appear as a cavity with a round or oval density within it, often surrounded by an air crescent, known as the "monad sign" or "air crescent sign."

 

 

Option C. Lung abscess: A lung abscess is typically seen as a cavity with an air-fluid level, where the top of the cavity shows air and the bottom contains fluid. The X-ray provided does not show such a cavity with an air-fluid level, making this option less likely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Miliary TB presents with numerous small, uniformly distributed nodules on a chest X-ray, resembling millet seeds. This pattern is a hallmark of disseminated tuberculosis.

choices.text: Albendazole is the drug of choice
Majority of infections are asymptomatic in humans
Infection is acquired by ingestion of aquatic plants

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the given image is correct? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Majority of infections are asymptomatic in humans

 

The given image shows hymenolepis nana egg. Egg is spherical or ovoid and has a thin colorless outer membrane and inner embryophore enclosing the hexacanth oncosphere. The space between two membranes contains yolk granules and 4-8 thread like polar. Filaments arising from two knobs on the embryophore. The eggs float in saturated solution of salt and are non-bile stained. They are immediately infective and unable to survive for more than 10 days in external environment.

 

Hymenolepis nana is the smallest and the most common tapeworm found in the human intestine.

 

Hymenolepiasis occurs more commonly in children. There are usually no symptoms but in heavy infections, there is nausea, anorexia, abdominal pain, diarrhea and irritability. Sometimes pruritus may occur due to an allergic response.

 

Praziquantel (single dose of 25 mg/kg) is the drug of choice, since it acts both against the adult worms and the cysticercoids in the intestinal villi. Nitazoxanide 500 mg BD for 3 days may be used as alternative.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Albendazole is the drug of choice: This is incorrect. The drug of choice for Hymenolepis nana is praziquantel (a single dose of 25 mg/kg) because it acts against both adult worms and the cysticercoids in the intestinal villi. Nitazoxanide (500 mg BD for 3 days) may be used as an alternative.

 

Option C. Infection is acquired by ingestion of aquatic plants: This is incorrect. The infection with Hymenolepis nana is not acquired through aquatic plants. Infections are usually acquired by ingestion of contaminated food or water or by autoinfection.

 

Option D. Non-segmented leaf-like parasite: This is incorrect. Hymenolepis nana is a segmented tapeworm, not a non-segmented leaf-like parasite.

 

Educational Objective

 

Hymenolepis nana (dwarf tapeworm) is the most common and smallest tapeworm in humans. Majority of infections are asymptomatic. The drug of choice is praziquantel.

 

Parasites with aquatic plants as the source of infection:

 

  • Fasciola hepatica
  • Fasciolopsis buski
  • Watsonius watsoni
  • Gastrodiscoides hominis

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl with primary amenorrhea has the following features. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2018)

 

  • Normal stature
  • Thelarche - absent
  • FSH, LH - high
  • Karyotype - 46 XX
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gonadal dysgenesis

 

Explanation:

 

The probable diagnosis in this case is pure gonadal dysgenesis. Primary amenorrhea with absent secondary sexual characteristics (thelarche) and high levels of FSH and LH indicate hypergonadotropic hypogonadism, which suggests an ovarian cause. The karyotype 46 XX confirms gonadal dysgenesis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Testicular feminizing syndrome/Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome

 

  • This condition occurs in individuals with a 46 XY karyotype.
  • Individuals with this syndrome have absent uterus and ovaries and exhibit secondary sexual development, especially breast development, due to peripheral production of estrogens.

 

Option C. Kallmann Syndrome

 

  • This is a cause of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism leading to primary amenorrhea.
  • It is associated with anosmia and absent secondary sexual characteristics.
  • FSH and LH levels are low in this condition.

 

Option D. Turner Syndrome

 

  • Characterized by a 45 XO karyotype.
  • Individuals have streak ovaries leading to low estrogen levels and absent secondary sexual characteristics.
  • FSH and LH levels are high.
  • A very important feature is short stature, which is not seen in the patient described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary amenorrhea with high FSH and LH levels and a 46 XX karyotype indicates gonadal dysgenesis.

 

Ref: Page no 454, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: Identify the structure marked with an arrow: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pulmonary trunk

 

The given image represents a cross-sectional view of the thorax, and the structure marked by the arrow is identified as the pulmonary trunk. The key points to identify the pulmonary trunk are its location and the surrounding structures in the thoracic cross-section.

 

  • Pulmonary Trunk: The pulmonary trunk is a major vessel that arises from the right ventricle of the heart and bifurcates into the right and left pulmonary arteries. It is situated anterior to the aorta and is clearly visible in the image as a large tube dividing into two branches.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carina: The carina is the point at which the trachea bifurcates into the left and right main bronchi. It is located lower in the thoracic cavity and is not associated with the structures visible in the image.

 

Option B. Superior vena cava: The superior vena cava is located to the right of the sternum and is not the structure marked by the arrow.

 

Option D. Arch of Aorta: The arch of the aorta is the curved portion of the aorta that gives rise to the brachiocephalic trunk, left common carotid artery, and left subclavian artery. In a cross-sectional view, it appears as an elongated structure, not as the large round structure marked by the arrow.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pulmonary trunk is a major vessel located anterior to the aorta, bifurcating into the right and left pulmonary arteries, and is the structure identified by the arrow in the cross-sectional image of the thorax.

choices.text: Uterine artery embolization

questions.text: A 33-year-old female patient comes with complaints of menorrhagia for the past 3 months. The duration and regularity of her menstrual cycles are normal. Non- hormonal management has been tried without success. What is the most appropriate next step? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hormonal therapy

 

Explanation:

 

  • Hormonal therapy is the next best management modality for menorrhagia when non-hormonal management has failed. This includes combined oral contraceptive pills or even progesterone-only devices like the LND-IUS.
  • First-line management includes non-hormonal treatment like NSAIDs and Tranexamic acid.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Uterine artery embolization: Uterine artery embolization is a surgical option and is considered when other treatments fail.

 

Option B. Endometrial ablation: Endometrial ablation is also a surgical option and should be considered after hormonal therapy.

 

Option D. Hysterectomy: Hysterectomy is the last resort and is used when all other management options fail or are contraindicated.

 

Educational Objective

 

Hormonal therapy, including combined oral contraceptive pills or progesterone-only devices like the LND-IUS, is the next best management step for menorrhagia when non-hormonal management has been ineffective.

 

Ref: Page no 197, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy was brought to the pediatric OPD with multiple abscesses over his face, chest, and back. The child has a history of recurrent respiratory infections. On examination, he has atopic excoriating skin and multiple cold abscesses on his back. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyper IgE syndrome

 

The clinical presentation of the boy with recurrent skin and respiratory infections, atopic excoriating skin, and notably, cold abscesses, strongly points towards Hyper IgE syndrome, also known as Job's syndrome. This condition is characterized by:

 

  • High levels of IgE: Elevated IgE is a hallmark of the syndrome and contributes to the immune dysregulation seen in these patients.
  • Recurrent infections: Due to defects in immune regulation, particularly affecting the response of neutrophils and other immune cells.
  • Dermatologic issues: Such as eczema and atopic dermatitis are common and often severe in these patients.
  • Genetic background: Hyper IgE syndrome is commonly caused by mutations in the STAT3 gene, which is critical for many aspects of immune system function, including the development and function of neutrophils.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyper IgM syndrome: Incorrect, characterized by elevated levels of IgM with low levels of other immunoglobulins, leading to a susceptibility to infections. It does not typically present with high IgE levels or eczema.

 

Option B. Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome: Incorrect, this is a condition that affects blood cells and immune response, characterized by thrombocytopenia, eczema, and recurrent infections; however, it does not typically involve high levels of IgE or cold abscesses.

 

Option D. Carcinoid syndrome: Incorrect, typically presents with symptoms caused by secreted hormones, such as flushing, diarrhea, and heart valve problems, which are unrelated to the immune dysfunction seen in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyper IgE syndrome should be considered in patients presenting with a combination of high IgE levels, recurrent skin and respiratory infections, and dermatologic issues such as eczema. Managing this condition often involves addressing the skin care comprehensively and preventing infections through vigilant monitoring and appropriate use of antibiotics.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male pt presented to your clinic with persistent non-pitting edema in their lower extremities as shown below. What could be the most likely reason for this symptom? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lymphedema

 

  • Lymphedema is the likeliest cause.
  • It involves the build-up of protein-rich fluid in tissue interstitial spaces.
  • It shows typical “non-pitting” edema in the second stage of lymphedema.
  • Filariasis is the most common etiology.
  • In severe and long standing cases, skin changes are seen giving the limb an appearance of “Elephantiasis”.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Arterial Disorders: Arterial disorders may lead to symptoms such as leg pain, intermittent claudication, and tissue damage due to reduced blood supply. Edema is uncommon.

 

Option C. Venous Disorders: These disorders can encompass conditions like deep vein thrombosis (DVT), varicose veins, chronic venous insufficiency (CVI), and venous ulcers. Venous disorders may result in symptoms like leg swelling, pain, and skin changes, and they can vary in severity. No evidence of skin changes associated with varicose veins are seen.

 

Option D. Coronary Heart Disease: Coronary heart disease (CHD), also known as coronary artery disease (CAD), is a common heart condition where the coronary arteries that supply blood to the heart muscle become narrowed or blocked due to the buildup of fatty deposits (atherosclerosis). CAD may lead to heart failure leading to bilateral lower limb pitting edema, which is not seen in the case above.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lymphedema is characterized by non-pitting edema due to the accumulation of protein-rich fluid in the tissue interstitial spaces. It can lead to significant swelling and skin changes, particularly in the lower extremities, distinguishing it from other causes of edema.

questions.text:
Which of the following are true about subclinical myocarditis? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Palpitations
  2. Elevated BNP Troponins
  3. Regional wall motion abnormalities in echo
  4. ECG suggestive of myocarditis
  5. Low LVEF in echo
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2,3,4,5


Subclinical myocarditis may not present with symptoms like palpitations, but can show:

 

2. Elevated BNP/Troponins: Indicating myocardial injury.

3. Regional wall motion abnormalities: Seen on echocardiography.

4. ECG changes: Suggestive of myocarditis, such as non-specific ST-T changes.

5. Low LVEF: Indicative of impaired left ventricular function.

 

Other Option:
 

1. Palpitations are not a feature of subclinical myocarditis.
 

Educational Objective:

 

Subclinical myocarditis can present with elevated cardiac biomarkers, regional wall motion abnormalities, ECG changes, and reduced LVEF, but not Palpitations, which is common in viral myocarditis.

 

Past common causes of myocarditis: Coxsackie virus types A and B.

 

 

Currently, Most common cause of myocarditis: Parvovirus B19 and HHV6.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with fever, night sweats, ptosis, and bilateral facial nerve palsy. Investigations showed leukocytosis and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sarcoidosis

 

The patient presents with fever, night sweats, ptosis, and bilateral facial nerve palsy. The investigations show leukocytosis and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy.

 

Hilar lymphadenopathy can be seen in many conditions like Sarcoidosis, Pneumoconiosis, TB, etc

 

But the other clinical features point towards sarcoidosis, a systemic inflammatory disease characterized by non-caseating granulomas. Sarcoidosis can affect multiple organs, but it commonly involves the lungs and lymph nodes. Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy is a hallmark finding in sarcoidosis and is often the first clue in diagnosis. Additionally, sarcoidosis can present with systemic symptoms like fever and night sweats.

 

The presence of bilateral facial nerve palsy is another significant clue. While Guillain-Barre syndrome, Lyme disease, and sarcoidosis can cause bilateral lower motor neuron (LMN) type facial palsy, the combination of other symptoms and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy strongly favors sarcoidosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tuberculosis: Tuberculosis (TB) can present with fever, night sweats, and lymphadenopathy, including hilar lymphadenopathy. However, TB typically causes caseating granulomas and does not commonly present with bilateral facial nerve palsy.

 

Option C. Lymphoma: Lymphoma can also present with fever, night sweats, and lymphadenopathy. However, it typically involves systemic B symptoms and other lymph node groups. Bilateral facial nerve palsy is not a common presentation of lymphoma.

 

Option D. Hypersensitive pneumonitis: Hypersensitive pneumonitis can present with respiratory symptoms and lymphadenopathy, but it is usually associated with exposure to inhaled organic antigens. It does not typically cause systemic symptoms like fever, night sweats, and bilateral facial nerve palsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy with systemic symptoms like fever and night sweats and the presence of bilateral facial nerve palsy is highly suggestive of sarcoidosis. Always consider sarcoidosis first in such clinical scenarios.

choices.text: Severe illness which is  constant threat to life

questions.text: Which of the following criteria corresponding to ASA grade III? (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Severe illness

 

Explanation:

 

Option D. Severe illness: The American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) Physical Status Classification System is used to assess and communicate a patient's pre-anesthesia medical co-morbidities. ASA grade III is defined as a patient with severe systemic disease that is not incapacitating. This means the patient has a serious illness, but it does not necessarily pose a constant threat to life, which would correspond to ASA IV.

 

Other Options:

 

 Option A. Mild illness: This corresponds to ASA II, which is defined as a patient with mild systemic disease. It does not reach the severity required for ASA III.

 

Option B. Moderate illness: This is not an official ASA classification term. The closest would be ASA II (mild systemic disease) or ASA III (severe systemic disease).

 

Option C. Severe illness which is a constant threat to life: This corresponds to ASA IV. It describes a patient with severe systemic disease that poses a constant threat to life, not ASA III.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ASA grade III corresponds to a patient with severe systemic disease that is not incapacitating.

 

The classification system is as follows:

 

  1. ASA I: A normal healthy patient.
  2. ASA II: A patient with mild systemic disease.
  3. ASA III: A patient with severe systemic disease that is not incapacitating.
  4. ASA IV: A patient with severe systemic disease that is a constant threat to life.
  5. ASA V: A moribund patient who is not expected to survive without the operation.
  6. ASA VI: A declared brain-dead patient whose organs are being removed for donor purposes.

questions.text: Which of the following is a contraindication to given drug? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Malpresentation of fetus

 

Explanation:

 

The given drug in the image is Oxytocin, which is commonly used to induce or augment labor. However, its use is contraindicated in several conditions to avoid complications during childbirth. One such contraindication is malpresentation of the fetus, where the fetus is not in a head-down position, potentially complicating a vaginal delivery.

 

Contraindications to Oxytocin:

 

  • Grand multipara: Women who have given birth five or more times.
  • Contracted pelvis: A pelvis that is too small to allow the passage of the fetus.
  • History of Classical Cesarean Section: Classical C-sections involve a vertical incision in the uterus, increasing the risk of uterine rupture.
  • History of 2 or more Lower Segment Cesarean Sections (LSCS): Multiple C-sections also increase the risk of uterine rupture.
  • Malpresentation: Includes breech, transverse, or any non-cephalic presentation of the fetus.
  • Obstructed labor: Labor that does not progress due to physical obstruction.
  • Fetal distress: Signs that the fetus is not well, such as abnormal heart rate patterns.
  • Hypovolemia: Reduced blood volume in the mother, which can complicate the use of oxytocin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Heart disease in mother: Heart disease in the mother is considered a relative contraindication for oxytocin administration. It requires careful monitoring and assessment by the healthcare provider, but it is not an absolute contraindication.

 

Option C. Premature labour: Oxytocin can sometimes be used to manage labor in preterm situations under strict medical supervision. It is not an absolute contraindication.

 

Option D. Hypothyroidism: Hypothyroidism is not a contraindication for the use of oxytocin. Proper management of hypothyroidism is necessary during pregnancy, but it does not specifically preclude the use of oxytocin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oxytocin is contraindicated in malpresentation of the fetus, grand multipara, contracted pelvis, history of classical cesarean, history of 2 or more LSCS, obstructed labor, fetal distress, and hypovolemia.

 

Ref: Page no 573, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 226th edition

questions.text: Match the following: (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A-4, B-1, C-2, D-3

 

  • Uro bags - collection of urine.
  • An underwater seal bag- collection of drainage fluid from the thoracic cavity.
  • Nasogastric tube / Ryle's tube - Used for Nasogastric feeding / Stomach wash / Aspiration
  • Metallic suction cannula - To clear the operative field by suctioning secretions/blood

questions.text: A young patient began taking a weight loss medication that works by preventing fat absorption from food. She developed easy bruising and increased menstrual bleeding after a few weeks. Which of the following vitamins deficiency is likely to be responsible for her condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin K

 

  • Vitamin A, D, E and K are fat soluble vitamins. Their absorption is hampered when the absorption of fat is prevented by a medication (eg Orlistat , Ezetimibe etc).
  • Vitamin K is required for the Gamma carboxylation of Glutamic acid residues of clotting factors 2 ,7 ,9 and 10 in order to activate them. If Vitamin K is deficient due to fat malabsorption, as in the above case, then there can be bleeding manifestations in the form of easy bruising and increased menstrual bleeding in females. The Prothrombin Time (PT) will be elevated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin E: Vitamin E deficiency can manifest as hemolytic anemia.

 

Option C. Vitamin B6: Vitamin B6 deficiency can be seen with drugs like Isoniazid, Penicillamine, Hydralazine, OCP. Patients can have peripheral neuritis, lowered seizure threshold, or convulsions.

 

Option D. Vitamin D: Vitamin D deficiency leads to the development of rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin K deficiency due to impaired fat absorption from weight loss medications can lead to bleeding manifestations such as easy bruising and increased menstrual bleeding.

questions.text: Banding technique used for dicentric chromosomes:(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) C

 

Explanation:

 

Dicentric chromosome is an abnormal chromosome with two centromeres.

 

 

C banding: stains heterochromatin which are regions of the chromosomes at or near centromere. So, C banding will be most useful for dicentric chromosomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. G-banding: G-banding is the most common banding technique and uses Giemsa stain to stain AT-rich regions. It was developed as an alternative to Q-banding due to the cumbersome nature of Q-banding.

 

Option B. NOR-banding: NOR-banding (Nucleolar Organizer Region) is used to stain regions associated with nucleolus formation and is not specifically useful for dicentric chromosomes.

 

Option D. R-banding: R-banding provides a reverse pattern to G-banding, staining GC-rich regions instead of AT-rich regions. It is not specifically useful for identifying dicentric chromosomes.

 

Note –  Q banding: uses quinacrine dye (first used dye) and stains repetitive AT rich regions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

C-banding is the preferred technique for identifying dicentric chromosomes as it specifically stains heterochromatin regions at or near the centromere.

 

Reference: Robbins 10th Ed. / page- 262-263, 293

questions.text: On performing a pulmonary function test, reduction in FEV1/FVC is characteristic of: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Obstructive disease

 

A reduction in the FEV1/FVC ratio (Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 second / Forced Vital Capacity) is characteristic of obstructive lung diseases. This ratio is a key indicator used to differentiate between obstructive and restrictive lung patterns on pulmonary function tests. In obstructive diseases, such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), asthma, and bronchiectasis, there is a disproportionate reduction in FEV1 relative to FVC due to airflow limitation and air trapping.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Restrictive disease: In restrictive lung diseases, both FEV1 and FVC are reduced proportionally, often leading to a normal or even increased FEV1/FVC ratio. Restrictive diseases include conditions such as pulmonary fibrosis and other interstitial lung diseases.

 

Option C. Normal lung function: Normal lung function would typically show an FEV1/FVC ratio within the normal range, which is generally above 0.7 in healthy adults.

 

Option D. Interstitial lung disease: This condition is a type of restrictive lung disease where there is a reduction in lung volumes, but the FEV1/FVC ratio is typically normal or increased, not reduced.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • FEV1/FVC reduction implies obstruction.
  • FEV1/FVC Increased or normal – Restrictive lung disease
  • Decrease in Maximum Mid-expiratory flow (MMEF) i.e., FEV25%-75% - Small airway disease

choices.text: Increased discharge of norepinephrine from the locus ceruleus

questions.text: Caffeine is a widely used stimulant that promotes wakefulness. Which of the following mechanisms is responsible for this effect? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adenosine antagonism

 

Caffeine exerts its stimulant effects primarily through the antagonism of adenosine receptors, specifically the A1 receptors in the brain. Adenosine is a neuromodulator that generally promotes sleep and relaxation by inhibiting neuronal activity. By blocking adenosine's action, caffeine prevents this inhibitory effect, leading to increased alertness and wakefulness.

 

Caffeine’s ability to keep you awake and alert is also related to its secondary effects, including the release of norepinephrine from the locus ceruleus and inhibition of phosphodiesterase, which increases cyclic AMP levels. However, the primary mechanism responsible for promoting wakefulness is the antagonism of adenosine receptors.

 

Remember - Side effects of ADEnosine antagonism:

 

  • A for Arrhythmias
  • D for Diuresis
  • E for Epileptic seizures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increased discharge of norepinephrine from the locus ceruleus: While caffeine can increase the release of norepinephrine, which is involved in alertness and arousal, this is not the primary mechanism for its wakefulness-promoting effects.

 

Option C. Release of histamine: Histamine release is associated with wakefulness, but this is not a direct mechanism of action for caffeine. Histamine release is more associated with other pathways in the brain.

 

Option D. Inhibition of phosphodiesterase: Caffeine does inhibit phosphodiesterase, leading to increased levels of cyclic AMP, but this mechanism is more relevant to its cardiovascular and smooth muscle effects rather than its role in promoting wakefulness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Caffeine is a widely used stimulant that promotes wakefulness through three main mechanisms:

 

  1. Inhibits phosphodiesterase enzyme.
  2. Acts as an adenosine A1 receptor antagonist.
  3. Releases norepinephrine from the locus coeruleus.

 

Caffeine promotes wakefulness primarily through the antagonism of adenosine receptors, blocking the sleep-inducing effects of adenosine and resulting in increased alertness

choices.text: Stria Gravidarum
Linea Alba
Linea Nigra
Stria albicans

questions.text: Identify the finding shown in image given below: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Linea Nigra

 

Explanation:

 

A hyperpigmented line from xiphisternum to pubic symphysis is Linea Nigra.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stria gravidarum: Stria gravidarum is a reddish stria of present pregnancy.

 

Option B. Linea Alba: The midline of the anterior abdominal wall skin. It takes on dark brown-black pigmentation to form the linea nigra.

 

 Option D. Stria albicans: Stria albicans is a silvery stria of previous pregnancies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A hyperpigmented line from xiphisternum to pubic symphysis is Linea Nigra.

 

Ref: Page no 79, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

choices.text: E1, E2, E5
E6, E7
L1, L2

questions.text: The image below shows the life cycle of a virus. Which of the proteins of the virus act as oncogenes?  (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) E6, E7

 

The image shows the life cycle of the human papilloma virus, and the E6 and E7 proteins act as oncogenes

 

 

  • HPV oncogenes E6 and E7 deregulate host cell cycle by binding and inactivating tumor suppressor genes p53 and pRb.
  • Binding of E6 gene to p53 causes degradation of p53.
  • E7 gene binds to pRb and disrupts the complex between pRb and E2F leading to uncontrolled proliferation. HPV, human papilloma virus.

 

 

 

Educational Objective

 

  • E6 and E7 proteins of HPV are the primary oncogenes responsible for the virus's ability to cause cancer. They do this by inactivating key tumor suppressor proteins, p53 and pRb, leading to uncontrolled cell growth and proliferation.

questions.text: A wife is complaining that her husband is not taking medications for his diabetes regularly and not maintaining his blood glucose for a long time. Which of the following markers is best for long-duration glucose analysis? (FMGE Jan 2024
questions.solution:
Ans. D) HbA1C

 

Explanation

 

HbA1c, or glycated hemoglobin, is the best marker for assessing long-term glucose control in diabetic patients. It reflects the average blood glucose levels over the past two to three months. This is because glucose binds to hemoglobin in red blood cells, and since red blood cells have a lifespan of about 120 days, the HbA1c value provides a long-term overview of blood glucose levels.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. RBS: Not suitable for long-term glucose control as it only measures blood sugar at a specific moment.

 

Option B. FBS: Provides fasting glucose levels but does not give a long-term picture.

 

Option C. PPBS: Useful for assessing post-meal glucose control but not for long-term analysis.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

HbA1c is the best marker for long-term glucose analysis in diabetic patients as it reflects average blood glucose levels over the past two to three months.

 

The target HbA1c for most patients with diabetes to ensure adequate control is less than 7%, though this may vary based on individual patient circumstances.

questions.text: Which type of translocation is seen in diaphyseal tumor with small blue round cells? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) T11, 22

 

The question refers to Ewing's sarcoma, a type of malignant tumor that typically affects the diaphysis (shaft) of long bones, particularly in children and young adults. The tumor is characterized by small, round, blue cells when viewed under a microscope. A hallmark of Ewing's sarcoma is the t(11;22) translocation, which fuses the EWSR1 gene on chromosome 22 with the FLI1 gene on chromosome 11. This translocation results in the production of an abnormal protein that drives the cancer.

 

This translocation, t(11;22), is highly specific for Ewing's sarcoma and is used as a diagnostic marker.

 

Mic 2 (CD99) – Most specific marker for Ewing’s sarcoma

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. EWSR1, WT1: This combination is incorrect for Ewing's sarcoma. While EWSR1 is involved, WT1 is a gene associated with Wilms' tumor, a kidney cancer, and is not involved in Ewing's sarcoma.

 

Option C. T15,17: This translocation is characteristic of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), not Ewing's sarcoma. The fusion of the PML and RARA genes occurs in APL.

 

Option D. T2,13: This translocation is associated with alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma, another type of soft tissue tumor, but not with Ewing's sarcoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The t(11;22) translocation is characteristic of Ewing's sarcoma, a diaphyseal tumor with small, round, blue cells, making it a crucial genetic marker for diagnosis.

questions.text: What blood group should be given to a patient with Bombay blood group? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Oh

 

The Bombay blood group, also known as the Oh phenotype, is one of the rarest blood groups in the world. It was discovered in 1952 by Dr Y.M. Bhende.

 

Individuals with this blood group lack the H antigen, which is a precursor to the A and B antigens found on the red blood cells of most individuals. The absence of the H antigen means that even blood type O, which normally has the H antigen, is not compatible with individuals who have the Bombay phenotype.

 

People with the Bombay blood group produce anti-H antibodies in addition to anti-A and anti-B antibodies. This means that they cannot receive blood from any of the common blood types (A, B, AB, or O), as all of these contain the H antigen and would lead to a severe transfusion reaction.

 

The only blood that can be safely transfused into a person with the Bombay blood group is blood from another Bombay blood group donor, which is denoted as Oh.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. AB: Individuals with blood group AB have both A and B antigens. This blood group would not be compatible with a Bombay blood group recipient, as it would cause a severe transfusion reaction due to the presence of H antigen.

 

Option B. O positive: Blood group O positive still has the H antigen, even though it lacks A and B antigens. Transfusing O positive blood into a Bombay blood group individual would also lead to a transfusion reaction.

 

Option D. O negative: Like O positive, O negative blood has the H antigen and would not be suitable for a Bombay blood group recipient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Bombay blood group (Oh phenotype) is extremely rare, and individuals with this blood type can only receive blood from another Bombay blood group donor due to the absence of the H antigen and the presence of anti-H antibodies.

questions.text: An elderly patient underwent investigations which revealed Hb 9 g/dL, TLC 50,000/mm³, ↑PT, ↑aPTT, low platelet count, and increased D-dimers. Which of the following is the likely gene affected in the patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) PML- RARA


The patient's presentation with anemia, elevated white blood cell count, prolonged PT and aPTT, low platelet count, and increased D-dimers is indicative of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

 

DIC is commonly associated with Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia (APL), previously known as AML M3. APL is characterized by a translocation between chromosomes 15 and 17, resulting in the PML-RARA fusion gene.

 

This fusion disrupts the normal function of the retinoic acid receptor, blocking the differentiation of promyelocytes and leading to an accumulation of immature cells. APL is strongly associated with DIC due to the procoagulant activity of the promyelocytes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. BCR-ABL: BCR-ABL is a fusion gene associated with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), resulting from the Philadelphia chromosome translocation (t(9;22)). It leads to unregulated tyrosine kinase activity, promoting proliferation of myeloid cells. It is not typically associated with DIC.

 

Option B. NPM: Nucleophosmin (NPM) mutations are associated with a subset of Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) without recurrent cytogenetic abnormalities, often presenting with a normal karyotype. It does not typically present with the coagulation abnormalities seen in DIC.

 

Option D. Inv 16: Inv(16) is associated with a specific subtype of AML (AML M4Eo), which involves abnormal eosinophils and monocytic cells. While it is an important genetic alteration in AML, it is not specifically linked with the coagulation issues seen in APL and DIC.

 

Educational Objective:


APL (acute promyelocytic leukemia) is characterized by the PML-RARA fusion gene and is highly associated with DIC, which can be identified by a combination of bleeding tendencies and abnormal coagulation profiles.

questions.text: Identify the type of hypoxia according to given graph: (Brown graph is normal) (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Anemic hypoxia

 

The given graph illustrates a 50% reduction in the oxygen saturation of hemoglobin, even though the partial pressure of oxygen (PO2) stays within the expected range. This state is termed anemic hypoxia.

 

Anemic hypoxia occurs when there is a reduction in the oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood, usually due to a lower amount of hemoglobin, as seen in anemia. Despite normal levels of PO2, the overall oxygen content in the blood is diminished, leading to insufficient oxygen delivery to tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stagnant hypoxia: This occurs when oxygen deficiency is due to poor blood circulation, not a reduced oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood. It is caused by issues like arterial obstruction or ischemia. The graph for stagnant hypoxia would show normal oxygen content in arterial blood but lower content in venous blood due to poor perfusion.

 

Option B. Histotoxic hypoxia: In this type, the cells are unable to utilize oxygen effectively, even though it is adequately supplied by the blood. This condition is typically caused by toxins like cyanide that impair cellular respiration. The graph for histotoxic hypoxia would show normal oxygen content in both arterial and venous blood since the issue is within the cells' ability to use oxygen, not the blood's ability to transport it.

 

Option C. Hypoxic hypoxia: This occurs when there is a generalized lack of oxygen in the body's tissues due to low oxygen in the blood, often seen at high altitudes or in conditions like COPD. The graph would show reduced PO2 along with decreased oxygen content in both arterial and venous blood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  1. Stagnant hypoxia: Oxygen deficiency due to poor blood circulation.
  2. Histotoxic hypoxia: Cells unable to utilize oxygen despite its availability.
  3. Hypoxic hypoxia: Generalized lack of oxygen in the body's tissues.
  4. Anemic hypoxia: Reduced oxygen-carrying capacity of blood due to low hemoglobin.

questions.text: Voltage-gated calcium channel present on T-tubule is: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dihydropyridine receptor

 

Explanation:

 

The T-tubules, or transverse tubules, are invaginations of the sarcolemma (muscle cell membrane) that play a crucial role in transmitting action potentials from the sarcolemma to the interior of the muscle fiber.

 

The voltage-gated calcium channels present on the T-tubules are known as dihydropyridine receptors (DHPR). These receptors are critical for the excitation-contraction coupling in muscle cells.

 

Dihydropyridine receptor: These receptors are voltage-gated calcium channels located on the T-tubules. When an action potential travels down the T-tubule, it activates the DHPR, which in turn mechanically activates the ryanodine receptor (RYR) on the sarcoplasmic reticulum, leading to the release of calcium ions into the cytoplasm and triggering muscle contraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ryanodine receptor: This receptor is also involved in calcium release but is located on the sarcoplasmic reticulum, not on the T-tubules. It is mechanically coupled to the DHPR in skeletal muscle.

 

Option C. SERCA: The Sarcoplasmic/Endoplasmic Reticulum Calcium ATPase (SERCA) pump is responsible for pumping calcium back into the sarcoplasmic reticulum, but it is not located on the T-tubules.

 

Option D. Nicotinic receptor: These are ligand-gated cation channels located at the neuromuscular junction on the sarcolemma, not on the T-tubules. They are responsible for initiating the action potential in response to acetylcholine but are not involved in calcium transport in the T-tubules.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The voltage-gated calcium channel present on the T-tubules is the dihydropyridine receptor (DHPR), which plays a crucial role in the excitation-contraction coupling in muscle cells.

questions.text: An 80-year-old woman presents with a progressive decline in daily activity. She gives a history of staring into space with frequent visual hallucinations. Pathology reveals Lewy bodies in neurons. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Parkinson’s Disease

 

The presence of Lewy bodies, which are aggregates of alpha-synuclein protein, in neurons suggests either Parkinson's disease or Lewy body dementia. Given the patient's symptoms of progressive decline in daily activity, visual hallucinations, and pathology findings, Parkinson's disease is the most likely diagnosis.

 

  • Lewy Bodies: These are characteristic of Parkinson’s disease and Lewy body dementia. They are intraneuronal inclusions primarily composed of alpha-synuclein.
  • Visual Hallucinations: These are more common in Parkinson's disease and Lewy body dementia compared to other neurodegenerative disorders.
  • Parkinson’s Disease: The diagnosis is supported by the clinical history of visual hallucinations and progressive decline, alongside the pathological finding of Lewy bodies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Prion’s Disease: Typically presents with rapidly progressing dementia and myoclonus. EEG shows characteristic periodic sharp wave complexes, and CSF may show elevated 14.3.3 protein. This does not match the patient's clinical picture.

 

Option C. Huntington’s Disease: An inherited condition characterized by the classic triad of dementia, chorea, and psychiatric manifestations. This condition usually presents earlier in life and has a strong family history component.

 

Option D. Alzheimer’s Disease: Primarily presents with memory loss and later with visual-spatial problems and the "four A’s" (amnesia, agnosia, apraxia, aphasia). Pathologically, it is characterized by beta-amyloid plaques and tau protein tangles, not Lewy bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Lewy bodies in neurons and clinical features such as visual hallucinations and progressive decline in activity are indicative of Parkinson’s disease.

choices.text: During palpation, over the left hypochondrium

questions.text: A 6-week-old infant is brought to the clinic with a history of projectile vomiting and poor weight gain. Physical examination reveals an abdominal mass in the epigastrium, and the diagnosis of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is suspected. An abdominal mass in a patient with congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is best seen? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. During feeding

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS) is a condition where the pylorus becomes hypertrophied and thickened. This leads to gastric outlet obstruction and symptoms such as projectile vomiting, dehydration, and electrolyte imbalances.

 

True. During feeding, or immediately after, the thickened muscle of the pylorus might be most palpable. As the stomach tries to empty its contents through the narrowed pylorus, the hypertrophied muscle can contract and become more prominent. This is called the "olive-like mass" which is palpable in the epigastrium to the right of the midline. This sign is pathognomonic for CHPS. The act of feeding induces peristaltic waves in the stomach, making the pyloric mass more prominent and easier to palpate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Soon after birth: CHPS typically presents in the third to fifth week of life, although it can be present at birth. It is rare to palpate the mass immediately after birth. The symptoms usually progress, and the hypertrophic pylorus becomes more palpable as the condition worsens.

 

Option C. During palpation, over the left hypochondrium: The pylorus is located on the right side of the abdomen, so palpating the left hypochondrium wouldn't help in detecting a mass related to CHPS.

 

Option D. During palpation, over the epigastrium: While the hypertrophied pyloric muscle can indeed be felt in the epigastrium, its palpability becomes much more distinct during or after feeding due to the reasons mentioned in option A. The epigastrium is the upper central region of the abdomen and is the location where the "olive-like mass" of CHPS is most frequently palpated.

 

Educational Objective:


In congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, the characteristic "olive-like mass" is most easily palpated during or immediately after feeding when the stomach contracts against the hypertrophied pyloric muscle.

choices.text: Encephalopathy, AST, albumin, bilirubin, Prothrombin time
Encephalopathy, ascites, albumin, bilirubin, prothrombin time

questions.text: Which of these are the components of Child Pugh score? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Encephalopathy, ascites, albumin, bilirubin, prothrombin time.

 

Encephalitis, ascites, albumin, bilirubin, Prothrombin time are the components of Child Pugh score

 

  • The Child-Pugh score is used to assess the prognosis of chronic liver disease and cirrhosis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The components of the Child-Pugh score include encephalopathy, ascites, bilirubin, albumin, and prothrombin time (INR). This scoring system is used to assess the prognosis of chronic liver disease and cirrhosis.

questions.text: The condition shown in the picture below is associated with which chromosomal abnormality? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 45XO

 

The image depicts a young female with features characteristic of Turner syndrome, which is associated with the chromosomal abnormality 45X0. Turner syndrome is characterized by a complete or partial absence of one of the X chromosomes. Key clinical features include short stature, webbed neck, widely spaced nipples, and delayed puberty. These physical findings align with the typical presentation of Turner syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 47XXY (Klinefelter syndrome): Klinefelter syndrome occurs in males and is characterized by the presence of an extra X chromosome (47XXY). This condition typically presents with tall stature, gynecomastia, and infertility, which do not match the features seen in the image.

 

Option C. 46X0 (XO mosaic): This option describes a mosaic form of Turner syndrome where some cells have a single X chromosome (45X0) while others have a typical female karyotype (46XX). While this is possible, the features described are more characteristic of classical Turner syndrome (45X0).

 

Option D. 48XY (Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome - AIS): AIS occurs in individuals with a male karyotype (46XY) but with insensitivity to androgens, resulting in incomplete or complete female external genitalia. However, AIS does not typically present with short stature, webbed neck, or widely spaced nipples, which are key features of Turner syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Turner syndrome (45X0) presents with short stature, webbed neck, widely spaced nipples, and delayed puberty. Recognizing these phenotypic patterns is crucial for diagnosing and managing patients with developmental and reproductive disorders.

questions.text: In osteoporosis, serum calcium and alkaline phosphatase levels are usually:(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Normal

 

OSTEOPOROSIS (V > H > C)

 

  • Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration.
  • Bone mineral density is measured by DEXA scan (65 years onwards)
  • Normal Ca2+, PO‑4, ALP
  • Hemiplegic – Humerus maximum loss of bone mineral density

 

 

  • Radiological Investigation: 
    • Quantitative CT is a newer imaging technique that can be used to detect osteoporosis
    • Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse) and codfish appearance (concave superior and inferior surfaces) of vertebrae.

 

 

Codfish vertebrae

 

  • Treatment:
    • Estrogen
    • Bisphosphonates – Increases hip fracture
    • Calcitonin
    • Low dose PTH – Stimulates osteoblasts

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In osteoporosis, the serum calcium and alkaline phosphatase levels remains normal. The bone density is decreased on the DEXA scan.

questions.text: What significant error did the intern make while creating a banner on measures to prevent the spread of non-communicable diseases, as assigned by a group of doctors?  (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Shift from PUFA to trans-fat

 

The significant error made by the intern while creating the banner on measures to prevent the spread of non-communicable diseases was the recommendation to "Shift from PUFA to trans-fat."

 

The other options, such as banning smoking in public areas, restricting alcohol selling/consumption, and decreasing additive salt on food, are appropriate measures to prevent non-communicable diseases.

 

However, the shifting from polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA) to trans-fats is incorrect, as trans-fats are one of the important risk factors for the development of non-communicable diseases. The recommendation should be to reduce trans-fat intake and promote the consumption of healthier fats like PUFA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ban smoking in public areas - This option is correct and should be included in the banner, as smoking is a major risk factor for non-communicable diseases.

 

Option B. Restrictions on alcohol selling/consumption - This option is correct and should be included in the banner, as alcohol consumption is a risk factor for conditions like coronary heart disease and hypertension.

 

Option D. Decrease additive salt on food - This option is correct and should be included in the banner, as even prudent diet (a diet for dietary goal achievement) says the salt intake should be <5gm/day.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The significant error made by the intern was recommending a shift from polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA) to trans-fats, as trans-fats are known to increase the risk of non-communicable diseases, contrary to the goal of preventing their spread.

choices.text: Part of kidney involved

questions.text: Which of the following is the most important determinant of malignant potential in the papillary type of renal tumor? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Size

 

The size of the tumor is the most important determinant of malignant potential in papillary renal tumors.

 

Renal tumors of the papillary type include:

 

  • Papillary adenoma of the kidney (</= 1.5 cm)
  • Papillary renal cell carcinoma (RCC) - greater than 1.5 cm

 

Small renal papillary growths are fairly common and are discovered by chance. One of the processes carried out during the evaluation of donor transplant kidneys is the ruling out of malignancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immunohistology: While useful for diagnostic and subtyping purposes, it is not the primary determinant of malignant potential. It helps identify the type of cells involved and the presence of specific markers.

 

Option C. Cytogenetics: Provides information on genetic abnormalities and can predict aggressiveness but is secondary to size in determining malignant potential.

 

Option D. Part of kidney involved: Although the location can affect treatment approaches and outcomes, it does not primarily determine whether a tumor is malignant; size is more predictive of malignancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In papillary renal tumors, the size greater than 1.5 cm is the most critical determinant in assessing malignancy, outweighing factors like immunohistology, cytogenetics, and part of the kidney involved in terms of initial evaluation.

questions.text: Rukmani is attending a Village Nutrition and Sanitation Programme. How frequently is it conducted? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Every month

 

The Village Health Sanitation and Nutrition Committee organizes a Village Health Sanitation and Nutrition Day once every month.

 

Rukmani is attending a "Village Nutrition and Sanitation Programme," which is likely referring to the Village Health Sanitation and Nutrition Day organized by the committee.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Village Health Sanitation and Nutrition Programme, which Rukmani is attending, is conducted once every month by the Village Health Sanitation and Nutrition Committee.

questions.text: Identify the following lines: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Blaschko lines

 

Blaschko lines, also known as Blaschko's lines, are an intricate and unique pattern of skin markings that follow a specific distribution on the human body. They are not visible under normal circumstances and only become apparent when certain skin conditions or genetic disorders manifest. They are thought to represent the migration and proliferation of embryonic cells during early development.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hinderer’s lines - Two intersecting lines, one from the ala to the tragus and one from the lateral canthus.

 

 

Option B. Marionette lines are wrinkles at the corners of mouth

 

 

Option C. Relaxed skin tension lines refer to furrows that are created when the skin is pinched and relaxed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blaschko lines offer a fascinating insight into human embryonic development and their pattern can help diagnose several dermatological conditions. Each of these lines has specific implications in medical practice, particularly in dermatology, plastic surgery, and cosmetic procedures, illustrating the intersection of clinical knowledge with aesthetic considerations.

questions.text: Match the following parasites with their respective hosts: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A-3, B-2, C-4, D-1

 

  • Diphyllobothrium latum: Humans (definitive host), Cyclops (first intermediate host), and Fish (second intermediate host).
  • Paragonimus westermani: Humans (definitive host), Snail (first intermediate host), Crayfish and Crab (second intermediate host).
  • Brugia malayi: Humans (definitive host), Mansonia mosquito (intermediate host).
  • Fasciola hepatica: Sheep and Humans (definitive hosts), Snail (first intermediate host), Aquatic vegetation (second intermediate host).

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: A school going child had applied henna and comes to dermatology OPD with the following lesions What is the possible diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dermatitis artefacta

 

The given image points towards a likely diagnosis of dermatitis Artefacta.

 

  • Dermatitis artefacta is a psychodermatological disorder where lesions are self-inflicted, often due to psychological stress or disorders. The pattern of the lesions, which are well-circumscribed and may follow an accessible pattern that the child could reach, is suggestive of dermatitis artefacta.
  • Dermatitis artefacta is a condition in which the patient deliberately produces skin lesions without any rational motive. This is a psychological ailment where the patient is fully aware of their actions.

 

Diagnosis:

 

  • Indicated by the symmetrical placement of lesions in accessible areas on the face, neck, chest etc. Additionally, the lesions may exhibit varying stages of healing, similar to an abrasion.
  • These visible symptoms of dermatitis artefacta can be seen as a form of nonverbal communication, representing a "cry for attention and help" from a patient who is unable to express their needs through meaningful verbal communication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Contact dermatitis due to henna:

 

  • Contact dermatitis from henna, often related to the chemical para-phenylenediamine (PPD), usually manifests as a diffuse, erythematous rash in areas where the henna was applied.
  • If the reaction were due to henna, one would expect to see an affected scalp where the henna was applied.
  • However, the presence of localized lesions on the cheek and the normal appearance of the scalp suggests that this is not a case of allergic contact dermatitis (ACD) caused by henna.

 

Option C. Polymorphic light eruption (PLE):

 

  • This is an abnormal reaction to sunlight it is not expected to have a direct correlation with the application of henna.
  • Lesions will be small, itchy papules or Papulo-vesicles on an erythematous background. They will also be monomorphic (unlike as the name suggests).

 

Option D. Vitiligo:

 

  • Vitiligo is characterized by depigmentation of the skin and would not present with erythematous or inflamed lesions as shown in the image.
  • It represents a loss of pigment and is not physically raised or inflamed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In assessing skin lesions, it's important to consider the psychological aspect of dermatology.
  • Dermatitis artefacta should be suspected in lesions that are localized, well-circumscribed, and do not have a distribution pattern consistent with the history or other physical causes.

 

Ref:

Rooks’ textbook of dermatology 9th edition 128.13

Kaplan & Saddocks concise textbook of clinical Psychiatry 11th edition page 435, 436

Fitzpatrick’s dermatology 9th edition 405

questions.text:
Acid-base imbalance is suspected in a patient. Which of the following would you use to determine it? (INICET MAY 2021)

 

  1. Arterial pH
  2. Venous pH
  3. Venous pO2
  4. Venous pCO2
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 4

 

Arterial pH is the gold standard for acid-base analysis as it directly measures the hydrogen ion concentration in arterial blood, providing a precise assessment of the patient's acid-base status. Venous pH and venous pCO2 can also provide reliable information about the patient’s acid-base status and are often used in clinical settings where arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis is not feasible.

 

1. Arterial pH and 2. Venous pH:  Arterial pH: This is the most accurate method for assessing acid-base balance. Arterial pH varies by only 0.03 to 0.05 from venous pH. To estimate arterial pH from venous pH, add 0.03 to 0.05.

 

4. Venous pCO2: To estimate arterial pCO2 (PaCO2) from venous pCO2, subtract 5 from venous pCO2.

 

Venous pH and venous pCO2 can be used in some situations to predict arterial values.

 

Other Options:
 

3. Venous pO2 is not useful for determining acid-base imbalance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Arterial pH, venous pH, and venous pCO2 are used to determine acid-base imbalances.

questions.text: Identify the site of the lesion: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Left occipital lobe

 

  • The visual field defect is right homonymous hemianopia with macular-sparing.
  • It is caused by lesions of the left occipital lobe, which is contralateral/crossing of fibers.
  • Head injury is a common cause of such lesions.
  • These lesions may be associated with visual hallucinations, denial of blindness (Anton syndrome), and the Riddoch phenomenon.
  • These lesions are commonly due to occlusion of the posterior cerebral artery. The part of the occipital lobe representing the peripheral field vision is supplied by the posterior cerebral artery.
  • The lesions generally spare the central vision/macular vision since the area at the tip of the calcarine cortex, representing the central macular vision, is supplied by a branch of the middle cerebral artery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right Occipital Lobe: This would cause a left-sided homonymous hemianopia.

 

Option C. Left Geniculate Body: Lesions here typically produce similar visual field defects as occipital lobe lesions but may have different associated clinical signs and symptoms.

 

Option D. Optic Chiasma: Lesions at the optic chiasm typically produce bitemporal hemianopia, which is not demonstrated in the visual field tests provided.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A lesion in the left occipital lobe is the most likely cause of the right homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing shown in the visual field tests. This understanding is critical for accurately diagnosing the underlying condition, potentially a vascular event, and directing appropriate management and intervention strategies.

questions.text: Imagine being part of a team aiming to identify the link between a novel nutritional supplement and its potential effects on muscle growth. You're tasked with deciding the most appropriate study design to establish a cause-and-effect relationship. Among the given options, which study design would be the most effective for demonstrating a connection between cause and effect? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Cohort study

 

  • Cohort study is the most effective study design for showcasing the connection between a cause and an effect. A cohort study is a type of analytical (observational) study used for ‘hypothesis testing’. It is known by several synonyms:
    • Prospective study
    • Forward looking study
    • Cause to effect study
    • Exposure to outcome study
    • Risk factor to disease study
    • Incidence study
    • Follow up study

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Case-control study: Case Control Study cannot provide with incidences, so Relative Risk cannot be calculated; In a Case Control Study, we calculate ‘an estimate of Relative Risk’, known as ‘Odds Ratio’ (CROSS PRODUCT RATIO).

 

Option C. Cross sectional study: A cross-sectional study is based on the single examination of a cross-section of a population ‘at one point of time’, results of sample are then projected to whole population. It cannot establish causality as ‘does not establish time sequence’.

 

Option D. Clinical trials: Clinical trials evaluates new studies, drugs and treatment effects on human population.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cohort studies are ideal for establishing cause-and-effect relationships by following exposures over time and observing outcomes.

questions.text: Fever occurs during inflammation due to all except: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Histamine 

 

Histamine is involved in the mediation of inflammatory vascular events rather than fever.

 

Fever is defined by an increase in body temperature of 1° to 4°C. It is a prominent manifestation of the acute-phase response, particularly when associated with infection.

 

Pyrogens are substances that cause fever. They can be either exogenous or endogenous.

 

  • Endogenous progens include IL-1, TNF, and prostaglandins.
  • Exogenous pyrogens are bacterial lipopolysaccharides that stimulate leukocytes to release endogenous progens (IL-1 and TNF)

 

Cytokines increase the activity of cyclooxygenases, which convert arachidonic acid into prostaglandins. These prostaglandins are produced in the hypothalamic vascular and perivascular cells. They stimulate the production of neurotransmitters in the hypothalamus, which raises the temperature setpoint. This is especially true of PGE2.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. IL-1, B. Prostaglandins and C. TNF: These are all endogenous pyrogens that directly contribute to the fever response by influencing the temperature regulation in the hypothalamus and stimulating the production of prostaglandins that raise the body’s temperature setpoint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Histamine is involved in mediating the local vascular effects of inflammation and not in the fever response, which is primarily driven by IL-1, TNF, and prostaglandins.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Child-Pugh scoring? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Creatinine

 

Explanation:

 

Child-Pugh scoring system is used to assess the prognosis of chronic liver disease, mainly cirrhosis. It involves five clinical measures of liver disease, including:

 

  1. Albumin
  2. Bilirubin
  3. Prothrombin Time (INR)
  4. Ascites
  5. Hepatic Encephalopathy

 

Creatinine is not included in the Child-Pugh scoring system. Instead, it is a component of the MELD (Model for End-Stage Liver Disease) score. The MELD score includes three parameters: creatinine, bilirubin, and INR. If it's MELD sodium, then it includes creatinine, bilirubin, INR, and sodium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Albumin: Albumin is a component of the Child-Pugh score. It helps assess the synthetic function of the liver.

 

Option B. Bilirubin: Bilirubin is another component of the Child-Pugh score. It indicates the liver's ability to excrete bile.

 

Option C. Prothrombin Time (INR): Prothrombin Time, measured as INR, is included in the Child-Pugh score to evaluate the liver's ability to produce clotting factors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Child-Pugh scoring system does not include creatinine as a parameter. Instead, creatinine is a part of the MELD score.

 

Note - The MELD score uses three parameters: Creatinine; Bilirubin and INR (International Normalized Ratio), so k/a CBI score. MELD Sodium Score includes Creatinine; Bilirubin; INR and sodium
